huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The Bighorn sheep population on the Henry's unit is stable to increasing. This is an incredibly beautiful place to hunt but it is a difficult hunt. The sheep are estimated to be about 100 in number and spread over a lot of area with little access from North Wash on the north to Good Hope Mesa on the south.  Within this area sheep are located at times along Lake Powell and the mesas and canyon drainages of Trachyte, Two Mile, Four Mile, Peshliki, and Ticaboo. They are also found on Mt Ellsworth, Mt. Holmes, and Mt. Hillers. The information on this webpage is meant to help guide you to areas that are likely to have sheep based upon harvest and observations, as well as other information to help you be successful on your hunt.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Sheep habitat is found between 3700' to 8500' and about 85 square miles on this unit. Hunters should be in excellent physical condition prior to the hunt as most hunters end up walking dozens of miles and traversing thousands of feet in elevation prior to harvesting their ram. As with most bighorn sheep habitat, there are steep impassible canyons and an abundance of cliffs. Be very careful scaling cliffs. It is advised that you bring extra rope and climbing gear to assist with getting through difficult ledges. A GPS unit is very handy on this unit to not only mark sheep and routes but also places where you can get through the ledges as they are relatively rare. Hunters can sometimes spend hours hiking along trying to find a way through the ledges and wasting time and energy. Bring plenty of water, there is very little on the unit.  Carry a good survival kit and a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety can be used if you decide to camp in an area without cell phone service and do not wish to travel to reach service. Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp, where you are hunting, and when you will return.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Temperatures can swing dramatically in November, be prepared for all weather conditions, pay attention to the weather forecast and use common sense.  Generally, plan on cold nights with mild days and little to no snow accumulation. Snow and bad weather is always possible in November. Be cautious of flash flooding during rain and thunder storms.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 60~200~153~~~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Suggested Hunting Area: Higher unit densities of desert bighorns based upon harvest and observations- between Ticaboo Creek and Four Mile Canyon, Trachyte Point above North Wash, and the east side of Mt Hillers. Lower densities areas- along the Lake Powell, on Mt. Ellsworth and Mt. Holmes, Maidenwater, Woodruff Canyon, Two Mile Canyon and associated canyon plateaus. Sheep often use cliff bands and the grassy benches between them, the rims of canyons, and the canyon bottoms. They are also often seen in the slick rock areas.

Scouting Tips: It’s good to be familiar with the area and understand if you have what it will take to find and harvest a mature ram before applying for this permit. You will need a good pair of binoculars and a good spotting scope. During the summer you will most likely see groups of ewes, lambs, and young rams. Older rams generally will not move into the area where the ewe groups are until the rut begins in late October. Hunting generally gets better the later you go with more mature rams showing up by November. Rams move a lot in November between ewe groups, so a single group of ewes and lambs can attract different rams from day to day.

Behavior: The peak of the rut tends to be the week of Thanksgiving or just prior to it. Rams will be moving from group to group looking for ewes. It is difficult to glass up rams but sometimes you can hear them butting heads as they compete with other rams to breed with the ewes. This can sound like a rifle firing through the canyons if you’re close enough. Sheep are generally active throughout the day in November but activity is highest in morning and evening. Bighorn sheep can go long periods without drinking water, acquiring moisture from vegetation that they eat. Bighorn will generally avoid the flat mesa tops where there is tree cover, but not always. Sheep use precipitous canyons and plateaus where the topography is steep with rough rocky outcrops. Between canyon ledges are often wider grassy slopes and shelves where sheep feed and which are corridors to other canyon layers and escape routes. Desert bighorn sheep have cloven hooves with harder sides/edges and softer inner pads. This adaptation allows them to quickly traverse steep rocky terrain to avoid predation. They are good at hiding under tight ledges and rocks.

Horn Growth: Both rams and ewes have horns. Mature ram horns are much larger than ewe horns and will form a curl. Mature ewes and yearling rams have similar curl; however, a ewe horn is thin and a yearling ram horn is much heavier especially at the base. 2.5 year old rams begin to have a pronounced curl, and rams that are 3 to 5 years old will have plenty of horn length but the horn tips are very thin. The best way to recognize mature trophy class bighorn rams is to look for horns closer to a full curl with horn mass, particularly out near the end of the horn. Mature rams 6 years and older have thicker heavier bases and the horns are thicker out near the ends only because older rams ‘broom off’ the thinner tips. During the rut horn growth nearly stops, creating annuli growth rings on the horn. The rate at which the horn grows in length steadily declines after 3.5 years of age, after about 8.5 years growth rings become less defined and their reliability to determine age drops dramatically. Often times if you are close enough, you can count horn rings on rams to get an approximate age. If you know the horn is broomed and heavy at the end then the second growth ring you see is most likely at 2.5 years old. The 2.5 yr and 3.5 year rings are often the most prominent with the 3.5 yr old ring being the deepest because it is associated with the ram’s first rut. The ear will usually point to this ring on a mature ram. If only one prominent ring is seen it is probably a 2.5 year old ram. By locating the 3.5 yr old ring you can determine or at least estimate the age of the ram by adding a year for each subsequent annuli growth ring.

Disease Issues: Bighorn sheep are highly susceptible to infection from respiratory pathogens. Between 30-70% of the herd can die if they become infected, and lambs born into the herd can continue to die after an outbreak. Bighorn sheep usually become infected through contact with domestic sheep or goats. These domestic animals carry the disease but aren't affected by it. While you are out scouting and hunting please report precise locations and numbers of any domestic sheep or goats in bighorn habitat to the local DWR office.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: After harvesting a bighorn sheep, you must bring the horns to a DWR office within 72 hours of leaving your hunting area. Checking in a bighorn sheep will fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement. If you received a bighorn sheep permit and did not hunt or did not harvest, you must complete your harvest survey online or by calling toll-free 1-800-221-0659 within 30 days of the season end date printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you being unable to apply for big game permits in subsequent years.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM. The National Park Service manages Glen Canyon National Recreation Area and Horse Shoe National Park. These areas are interspersed with SITLA land. There is is also private land on Mt. Ellen, Mt. Hillers, and leased land on Mt. Holmes.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: There are no DWR Wildlife Management Areas
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There are three managed campgrounds on the Henry Mtns. Two on Mt Ellen: Lonesome Beaver and McMillan, and Mt. Hillers: Star Springs. Direct questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Hanksville BLM Field Office. http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/richfield/recreation_/henry_mountains.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
Deer, Bison, Elk: There are several Henry Mountain access roads. Mount Ellen can be accessed on the North from the Sawmill Basin road, travel south on 100 East in Hanksville. Access to the east side of Mt Ellen is from the Little Egypt road at mile marker 20 off of SR95. Access to the west side of Ellen and Pennell is off the Notom/Burr Trail road, turn east at the Sandy Ranch. The east side of Mount Pennell and the north side of Mount Hillers can be accessed from the Coyote Benches/Stanton Pass road off of SR276. The east and south side of Mount Hillers can be accessed from the Star Springs road also off of SR276. All these roads connect with each other so there is general access to various areas across the mountain range.The BLM has put up good signage to get you around.

Desert Bighorn Sheep: Some of the best access is from Lake Powell on the east side of the unit. From the lake you can access Trachyte, Two Mile, Four Mile, Peshliki, and Ticaboo drainages. SR95 through North Wash follows along the North side of the unit and hwy 276 which travels along the west side of Mt. Holmes and Elsworth and the east side Mt. Hillers. From the map you will see a few stem roads going east off of SR276. One accesses Trachyte Point for about 3 miles where it ends above Hog Springs. Another road stems towards Mt. Holmes and Fred Ridge but this soon dead ends at a private property gate. Another road stems also to Mt. Ellsworth. Ticaboo Mesa is also accessed from SR276, this road runs along the southern side of Mt. Ellsworth and overlooks the canyon forks of Ticaboo Creek and other canyons and mesas to the North.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS:
The following link on the BLM website provides a good map of the general boundaries of the five BLM Wilderness Study Areas (WSAs) located in the hunt unit surrounding the Henry Mountains, as well as the motorized travel designations which presently exist on public lands in this area. This map is available at: https://www.blm.gov/sites/blm.gov/files/uploads/BLMUtahHenryMountainsMap.pdf
USGS maps are available at the BLM in Hanksville: USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Escalante, Hanksville, Hite Crossing, and Loa. They have a general map that labels most of the main roads. The BLM also has good road signage to help you navigate.
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO:
Emery County: http://www.emerycounty.com/road/contact.htm
Wayne County: http://www.waynecountyutah.org/
Garfield County: http://garfield.utah.gov/
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Deer and Bison: 4 wheel drive is highly recommended on the Henry Mountains. Roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, Wayne and Garfield counties, and SITLA, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans. The Cave Flat road has a temporary closure November 1st – May 15th. Direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Hanksville BLM Field Office, SITLA, and the county you are traveling. http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/richfield/recreation_/henry_mountains.html

Desert Bighorn: The few stem roads east off of SR276 would be best with an ATV. Direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Hanksville BLM Field Office, SITLA, and the county you are traveling.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The boundary excludes all of the Capital Reef National Park (CRNP). CRNP strictly regulates all hunting activity and access through the Park which is limited to the Swap Canyon trail on foot or by horse. At the end of the Cow Bison Orientation is detailed information about bison hunting and CRNP. You can see the orientation here. Contact Capital Reef National park for more information. http://www.nps.gov/care/contacts.htm

There is private property on both Mount Ellen and Mount Hillers. Mount Holmes also has private leased property. Written permission from the landowner/lessee is required by law to access and hunt private land.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Garfield, Kane and Wayne counties--Boundary begins on SR-95 at a point two miles south of Hanksville; south on SR-95 to Lake Powell; south along the west shore of Lake Powell to SR-276 at Bullfrog; north on SR-276 to the Burr Trail-Notom road; north on this road to the Capitol Reef National Park boundary; north on this boundary to the Burr Trail-Notom road at The Narrows and Divide Canyon; north on this road to a point two miles south of SR-24; east along a line that is two miles south of SR-24 to SR-95. EXCLUDES ALL NATIONAL PARKS. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Escalante, Hanksville, Hite Crossing, Loa. Boundary questions? Call the Price office, 435-613-3700.
